review.title: Spectral Compressed Sensing via Structured Matrix Completion
review.abstract: The paper studies the problem of recovering a spectrally sparse object from a small number of time domain samples. Specifically, the object of interest with ambient dimension $n$ is assumed to be a mixture of $r$ complex multi-dimensional sinusoids, while the underlying frequencies can assume any value in the unit disk. Conventional compressed sensing paradigms suffer from the {\em basis mismatch} issue when imposing a discrete dictionary on the Fourier representation. To address this problem, we develop a novel nonparametric algorithm, called enhanced matrix completion (EMaC), based on structured matrix completion. The algorithm starts by arranging the data into a low-rank enhanced form with multi-fold Hankel structure, then attempts recovery via nuclear norm minimization. Under mild incoherence conditions, EMaC allows perfect recovery as soon as the number of samples exceeds the order of $\mathcal{O}(r\log^{2} n)$. We also show that, in many instances, accurate completion of a low-rank multi-fold Hankel matrix is possible when the number of observed entries is proportional to the information theoretical limits (except for a logarithmic gap). The robustness of EMaC against bounded noise and its applicability to super resolution are further demonstrated by numerical experiments.
histories: accepted to International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML 2013)
accepted to International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML 2013)

sections.text: The above experiments were performed with the aforementioned SDPT3 (such as SeDuMi), which are generally not applicable to large-scale data. sections.heading: 5.3. Super Resolution
sections.text: The proposed EMaC algorithm uses the random observation model in Theorem 1. Fig. 3 to consider an example of synthetic super-resolution, where the basic truth in Fig. 3 (a) contains 6-point sources with constant amplitude. Low-resolution observation in Fig. 3 (b) occurs by measuring low-frequency components [− flo, flo] of the basic truth. Due to the large width of the associated point-spread function, both the positions and amplitudes of the point sources in the low-resolution image are distorted. We use EMaC to extrapolate high-frequency components to [− fhi, fhi] where fhi / flo = 2. The reconstruction in Fig. 3 (c) is achieved by applying the directly inverse Fourier transformation of the spectrum to avoid parameter estimates such as the number of modes.

sections.heading: 6. Structured Matrix Completion
sections.text: One problem closely related to our method is the completion of the K-fold Hankel matrix from a small number of entries. Consider, for example, the 2-D model. While each spectral-sparse signal can be assigned to a low-level 2-fold Hankel matrix, it is not clear whether all 2-fold Hankel matrices of rank r can be written as an extended form of an object with spectral rarity r. Therefore, the restoration of the K-fold Hankel matrix can be thought of as a more general problem than the spectral-compressed sensor problem. In fact, Hankel Matrix completion has found numerous applications in system identification (Fazel et al., 2011), natural language processing (Balle & Mohri, 2012), computer vision (Sankaranarayanan et al., 2010), medical imaging (Shin et al., 2008), etc.There have been several works on Hankel algorithms and full Hankel experiments;

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: We present an efficient non-parametric algorithm for estimating a spectral sparse object from its timeshare domain samples, which presents spectral compressed sampling as a minor Hankel matrix completion problem. Under mild conditions, our algorithm allows the restoration of multidimensional unknown frequencies with infinite precision, eliminating the problem of fundamental mismatch that occurs in conventional CS paradigms. To our knowledge, our result on Hankel matrix completion is also the first theoretical guarantee close to the information theory limit (up to a logarithmic factor).

Conventional approaches for these problems, such as ESPRIT (Roy & Kailath, 1989) and the matrix pencil method (Hua, 1992), are based on the eigenvalue decomposition of covariance matrices constructed from equi-spaced samples, which can accommodate infinite frequency precision.
Besides, their performance largely depends on the knowledge of noise spectra; some of them are unstable in the presence of noise and outliers (Dragotti et al., 2007).

It has been shown (Candes & Recht, 2009; Gross, 2011) that exact recovery is possible via nuclear norm minimization, as soon as the number of observed entries is on the order of the information theoretic limit.

However, generic matrix completion algorithms (Gross, 2011) require at least the order of rmax (n1, n2) samples, which far exceeds the degrees of freedom (which is O (r logn) due to a coupon collector’s effect) in our problem.

The EMaC method has similar spirit as the well-known matrix completion algorithms (Candes & Recht, 2009; Gross, 2011), however the additional Hankel or blockHankel structures on the matrices make existing theoretical results inapplicable in our framework.
Nevertheless, the golfing scheme introduced in (Gross, 2011) lays the foundation of our analysis.
The dual certificate is constructed via the golfing scheme introduced in (Gross, 2011).

metadata.abstractText: The paper studies the problem of recovering a spectrally sparse object from a small number of time domain samples. Specifically, the object of interest with ambient dimension n is assumed to be a mixture of r complex multi-dimensional sinusoids, while the underlying frequencies can assume any value in the unit disk. Conventional compressed sensing paradigms suffer from the basis mismatch issue when imposing a discrete dictionary on the Fourier representation. To address this problem, we develop a novel nonparametric algorithm, called enhanced matrix completion (EMaC), based on structured matrix completion. The algorithm starts by arranging the data into a low-rank enhanced form with multi-fold Hankel structure, then attempts recovery via nuclear norm minimization. Under mild incoherence conditions, EMaC allows perfect recovery as soon as the number of samples exceeds the order of O(r log n). We also show that, in many instances, accurate completion of a low-rank multi-fold Hankel matrix is possible when the number of observed entries is proportional to the information theoretical limits (except for a logarithmic gap). The robustness of EMaC against bounded noise and its applicability to super resolution are further demonstrated by numerical experiments.
